title: Why are some of my questions no longer receiving any views? - Quora

response.answer_text: I suspect that your questions are not receiving views because people are viewing them but scrolling past them instead of clicking on them.  According to your profile, you have been a professor since 2014. For someone in a senior academic position, I find some of your questions puzzling: How do Islam’s make their money? I assume that you mean Muslims. The same way that everyone else does, apart from a few exceptions limited by Islam. What makes Mexicans bad? Are they? All Mexicans? Why can’t young people be very good at video games? In my experience, young people tend to be good at video games. Why does your body hallucinate after staying awake for too long? Your body does not hallucinate. It is a mental issue. How long would it take someone to swim across the Detroit river? Where, at the widest point? Who is the best supermodel? By what measure? Has anyone climbed the tallest building every time? What does this mean? How many holes are in a golf ball? Perhaps you mean dimples. What if you break one of the monastic rules? This depends on whether you are a monk. Why did it take so long for England to try and wipe out America? I live in England and I was unaware of this. Why do people distant themselves? Perhaps you mean “distance”. And so on…

This is similar to Facebook.Every time, a friend of yours posts a status, someone likes and comments. That feed shows up in other profiles, this chain continues.Lesser the likes and comments, lesser the views. ( You can try this by commenting on an old photo of your friend, if the post is public, it will show up in your’s as well as your friend’s feed!) On Quora.When you ask a question, make sure you request the question to the allowed 15–20 people who are connected to that particular field. If any of them answers, their followers will know about it in their feed, when they upvote their answer, it will show up in their follower’s feed. The chain continues. The answers which go viral with huge upvotes and comments are a digital representation of “Ripple Effect”.
